I want to clarify some things.
J0523 may be smaller in size then Jupiter, but its density and mass are far greater then Jupiter. Otherwise it couldn't sustain nuclear fusion. And thus wouldn't be considered a star. And that`s how that is possible to have a star that is smaller then Jupiter in size, but yet Jupiter isn't a star.

Got a video idea for you, though it may be a little over the heads of the pubic visiting this site, including mine.  How far does a star have to be from the sun to keep from destroying the Earth when it goes supernova.  I realize there are several kinds of supernovas, so the answer may be too involved for this format.  For example, stars less than 3 times the sun's mass, are probably incapable of doing so.  I read a debate 20+ years ago in a series of a sci-fy magazine editorial sections, using back-of-the-envelope level math.  Which seemed to reach several different conclusions.  This was before Gamma Ray Bursts were an item, and Type 1-A's were seen as standard candles, etc..  So that might explain the discrepancies.   It would seem to be more than an academic interest, since there are several stars of qualifying mass within a hundred light years, and several late in life candidates within approximately 1000 light years.  Then, again, maybe you'd prefer to direct my attention to already published data.

Summary of what you taught me:
A) UY Scuti - If you are the biggest in the room you are not the brightest. Good news - not the densest either.

B) 2MASS J0523-1403 -- Being small does not intellect make. But being small and dim is not a sin - even if you are denser than tin.

C) PSR J1311-3430 The Black Widow spins for its mate --- And in time all will be ate --- But after its meal a sad fate --- A lonely star and that's not great.

D) SMS J031300.36-670839.3 Does one get old by staying away from Heavy Metal, or do the old stay away from Heavy Metal?

E) HV 3112 -- If you are big and explosive, you can still protect you smaller siblings. Or maybe just eat them.

(Yes, I probably have too much free time on my hands)

I wonder about this star that is "impossible to age". If it is so old, wouldn't all its elements have fused together at some point? How long does it take for a star of a certain mass (density+size) to "age" in that way, so it will finally "burn out" (or go supernova)? Would it be possible for SM0313 to have been around since a few hundred million years after the big bang and still be shining bright, like a star does? Couldn't that be calculated, considering its mass/the number and type of atoms in it, as well as its brightness (the rate at which its fusion process progresses)? I mean, a star certainly can't live forever, since it's also bound by the laws of physics?
